subject: Voted
event: Just got back from the courthouse, where I cast my vote. It was a busy, bustling scene. The poll watchers and election personnel told me that early voting is way up compared to 2012, at least in Santa Fe County. That's encouraging. After you cast your ballot, they give you one of those little red, white, and blue I VOTED stickers. We want to do our own part in encouraging everyone to get out and vote, so from now until November 9 anyone who turns up at the Jean Cocteau Cinema with one of those stickers will get a FREE POPCORN. No charge for butter, or the topping of your choice. And we do have the best popcorn in town, so... I have to admit, this election has me very anxious, especially this past week as the polls began to tighten. Every four years someone is sure to say, "This is the most important election of our lifetime," but this year I think that is absolutely true. In other words: vote. Do it for America, do it for the world, do it for your children, do it for the popcorn... but DO IT.

comments.article: Did you vote for adult Joffrey or Cersei?

comments.article: I must admit I am starting to get a little annoyed that I have to wait until election day to vote in PA. If I could vote, than I could pretend the election was over.
comments.subject: Congrats

comments.article: Obviously you wrote characters like Euron a long time before 2016, but do you feel like you've grappled with what motivates the base of supporters through your writing?
Voted here in Houston on the 1st day (last Monday). We've had record early voting turnout for each day! No "buffoons" here, thanks.
comments.subject: Early voting -

comments.article: LONG MAY SHE REIGN!
I'll be voting on Election Day in New York.  I will NOT be voting for Trump.
The election has been making me very anxious too. I'm looking forward to voting for Hillary, but I wish I lived in a swing state where my vote mattered more! Darn the electoral college.
Are the little hearts at the bottom of posts a new LiveJournal feature?
comments.subject: Hearts

comments.article:
Yes. They are some sort of "like" feature for approving of posts that you enjoy.

I think.
comments.subject: Re: Hearts

comments.article: You have mentioned a couple of times that being a good king doesn't mean you are a good person, and being a good man doesn't necessary make you a good king. Is it possible that a bad person could become a good president?

In theory, sure. History is full of bad men who were good kings, if you define "good" as meaning "made their country richer and more powerful," etc. Edward I of England probably falls into that category, along with Philip IV and Louis XI of France, and maybe Louis XIV as well.

Of course, there are also plenty of bad men who were bad kings as well, and led their countries to ruin and destruction.

In an election cycle like this, it must be extremely frustrating for non-Americans to have no voice in whether the largest economy and most powerful military on the planet falls under the control of an impulsive and ignorant narcissist who has, on multiple occasions, questioned why we have nukes if we can't use them. Or who thinks climate change is a Chinese hoax. Or who wants to default on U.S. debt so he can 'make a better deal.'

A single vote in this contest isn't much, but I'm guessing a lot of people around the world would kill for that one vote right now.

You are absolutely correct. I know a lot of my fellow Canadians are kind of heartsick right now about the whole thing. (Keep in mind that even the most conservative Canadian province - Alberta - is still pretty darned liberal by US standards.)

I imagine (based on your comments this past year) you didn't vote for Trump, so did you go with Clinton or with one of the third party options?
Since you are a registered Democrat, did you vote in the primaries? what's your opinion on Sanders?
comments.subject: Who did you vote for?

comments.article: It's amazing how you had Donald Trump in mind decades ago when you created Joffrey Baratheon as a character.

Mr. Martin,

Who did you vote for?
As a good resident of New Mexico you voted Johnson/Weld right? ;-)
I thought the libertarian ticket was Johnson/Weed

Best of Luck, Amerecia

from an Australian.
Me too. Though I was born in america so this election has me worried as well (But to be fair I am sure everyone is worried about this election whether they are american or not)
I'm so envious of those of you in states with early voting. Here in Pennsylvania, it doesn't exist and efforts to implement have failed.
It does make things much easier.  You do not have to contend with the long lines and lengthy waits that you often encounter on election day.

As an american citizen who lives in Australia I can only sit back and watch from the sidelines sadly. But I am hoping that Trump doesn't win and honestly to me this election has been just torture to watch to the point were not even John Oliver can cheer me up with his jokes about the whole election anymore (And I think he is hilarious).
John Oliver is brilliant.

We all want the candidate we think will best serve Americans interests.  Not all your fans are democrats,  and what mike rowe said about celebrity get out the vote campaigns was spot on.  Always a fan of your work regardless.
comments.subject: Voted

comments.article: I love Mike Rowe. I think he is brilliant man.
comments.subject: RE: Voted

comments.upictitle: Prof. Jeremy M. R. F. Chesterfield-Pickles III: Chthonic Phil
comments.article:
Sadly, I almost didn't get to vote...I didn't receive a ballot in the mail, and when I went into the auditor's office today to inquire on that, they had lost my voter registration...luckily, I had been previously registered in another county, so they were able to get my registration transferred, but couldn't give me a ballot for my current county, so I had to vote for officials in a place I no longer live...but, I did get to vote for our Senator and House of Reps and the President, which are the really essential things this time around (and several of the races in the other county are uncontested).

Whatever else this election has raised as issues of concern nationally, politically, and culturally, the accessibility of voting and voting rights is certainly one of them...as a disabled person, this is especially infuriating for a variety of reasons I'll be writing to the county auditor about.

Grumble, grumble, grumble...

I do believe what South Park says about these elections, that Trump is a little scared with the prospect of winning. Saying some angry comments in front of a camera may be easy. Entering the oval office with absolutely no knowledge of ruling...a completely different story. I 'd vote for the less dangerous if I were American. But I do hope more than two political ideologies will fing fertile ground in the U.S.A. someday.

I honestly have a theory that if he wins, he will just brag about how he proved he could win and leave the office for Mike Pence.
Sure, a lot of people would feel betrayed, a lot would feel relieved but I mean, I don't know how exactly are the american laws regarding a politician and whatever assets he may have that could lead to a conflict of interest, but I don't think he would like to sell a great portion of his shares and assets to become president. (then again, I might be talking from my ass, so someone feel free to enlighten me on this deal).
This whole election feels like Star Wars Episode III in real life.
Yeah it does. I wonder what trumps version off order 66 will be if he is elected (most likely something horrible).
My lovely wife said it best " I'd rather tread water with Hillary than sink with trump". No two ways about it, these are some frightening times we live in.

Did that voting thing on Saturday. Was the only one in the place. I do so love early voting! Now I can ignore it all until Nov 8 when I just have to watch to see who actually wins what.
I really tried to convince my sons who are in their 20s and live in Texas to go and vote, but neither seemed to see a point. It's amazing how much times have changed. I was thrilled when I first had the opportunity to vote.
I have to say I will just be glad when this is all over. Then we can start worrying about the dysfunction in Congress.

They don't see a point?

sigh
